transliteration:
trīṇy ādyāny āśritās tveṣāṁ mṛga-gartāśrayā apcarāḥ |
trīṇy uttarāṇi kramaśaḥ plavaṅgamā narāmarāḥ || 7.72||
sph_interpretive_translation: Three lower categories rest in animal dens and caves; three upper ones progressively inhabit birds, humans, and gods.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority flows through conscious evolutionary capacity
Causation aligns with sequential embodiment integrity
Capacity-based responsibility increases with form complexity
Restoration logic follows natural hierarchical ascent
supreme_court_application: Supreme Court adjudicates based on embodiment level and corresponding dharmic capacity. Lower forms receive protection and completion pathways. Higher forms are held fully accountable for restoring universal dharma without punitive interference.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that beings evolve through successive embodiments according to their karmic readiness. Each stage reflects a measurable capacity for dharma alignment. Responsibility arises naturally from capability, not imposed judgment. Sequential manifestation ensures proportional awakening without external coercion.
final_declaration: By the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, this law stands established: Dharma operates through conscious evolution, not punitive force. All beings ascend by inherent capacity, guided by non-coercive restoration. Reality itself enforces harmony when aligned with Source-consciousness.
